metadata.title: Keggin type of cesium phosphomolybdate synthesized via solid-state reaction as an efficient catalyst for the photodegradation of a dye pollutant in aqueous phase

Fig. 1 Powder X-ray pattern of Cs3PMo12O40 (CsPM). Fig. 2 (a) Ultraviolet–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of H3PMo12O40 (HPM) and Cs3PMo12O40 (CsPM), (b) (αhυ)2 as a function of photon energy (hυ). Fig. 3 The changes in UV–vis absorption spectra of BR46 solution during the photocatalyticprocess at different irradiation times. Fig. 4 Photocatalytic degradation of BR46 by TiO2 and CsPM under the simulated sunlight irradiation (λ >380nm): Catalyst dosage=2g/L, time irradiation=90min and initial dye concentration=10mg/L. Fig. 5 Comparison of scavenging efficiency of AgNO3, (NH4)2C2O4 and hydrogen peroxide (as promoter) and synthesis method on the photocatalytic degradation of BR46. Catalyst dosage=2g/L, scavenger concentration=10mg/L, concentration of H2O2 =2mM and initial dye concentration=10mg/L. Fig. 6 Initial adsorption of BR46 on CsPM after 30min darkness and photocatalytic degradation after 90min irradiation: catalyst dosage=2g/L, and initial dye concentration=10mg/L, concentration of H2O2 =2mM, concentration of scavenger=10mg/L. Table 1 Effect of the presence of sulfate, carbonate and chloride (as radical scavengers) on the photocatalytic degradation of BR46. Catalyst dosage=2g/L, and initial dye concentration=10mg/L. Scavenger Scavenger concentration (mg/L) Degradation efficiency (%) No scavenger 0 94 Sulfate 5 84 25 79 50 69 100 61 Carbonate 5 78 25 61 50 58 100 42 Chloride 5 69 25 57 50 46 100 35 Keggin type of cesium phosphomolybdate synthesized via solid-state reaction as an efficient catalyst for the photodegradation of a dye pollutant in aqueous phase Hooman Rezaei Ghalebi a Soheil Aber a ⁎ Afzal Karimi b a Research Laboratory of Environment Protection Technology, Department of Applied Chemistry, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran Research Laboratory of Environment Protection Technology Department of Applied Chemistry University of Tabriz Tabriz Iran b Department of Chemical Engineering, Faculty of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran Department of Chemical Engineering Faculty of Chemical and Petroleum Engineering University of Tabriz Tabriz Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 41 3339 3153; fax: +98 41 3334 0191. Graphical abstract Here the potential use of cesium phosphomolybdate salt as a photocatalyst for the photodegradation of dye pollutants was studied. Polyoxometalates salts, having Keggin structure with large cations like Cs+, are porous materials. Cs3PMo12O40 salt was prepared by solid-state method with a much higher surface area than the original Keggin-type heteropolyacids (H3PMo12O40). The morphological and structural studies of synthesized nanoclusters were carried out using field emission scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, energy dispersive analysis by X-ray and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy determined the absorption edge and band gap energies of the prepared salt as a direct semiconductor. The optical energy gap was calculated equal to 2.35eV. The cesium phosphomolybdate nanocluster exhibited high photodegradation ability for basic red 46 (BR46) under the simulated sunlight. The trapping experiments indicated that the photogenerated hydroxyl radicals and holes were the main responsible for the BR46 photodegradation. The presence of H2O2 significantly improved the photocatalytic activity of cesium phosphomolybdate. The Cs3PMo12O40 catalyst was very stable and easily separated from the reaction media for reuse. Keywords Cesium phosphomolybdate nanoclusters Photocatalysis Photocatalytic degradation Polyoxometalate 1 Introduction Among various physical, chemical, and biological technologies used in pollution control, the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), including the Fenton reaction, photocatalysis, sonolysis, ozonation, and combinations of these methods, are increasingly adopted in the destruction of organic contaminants, due to their high efficiency, simplicity, good reproducibility, and easy automation and control [1–5]. The AOPs are based on the in situ generation of hydroxyl radicals (OH), highly powerful oxidizing agents, and are effective in treatment of persistent organic pollutants in aqueous solutions until their overall mineralization [6,7]. Among the most promising AOPs for wastewater treatment, using photocatalytic reaction in an aqueous system is particularly attractive and has been investigated in numerous studies [8,9]. The photocatalytic water purification has proven to be an efficient, green and promising remedial technology, which can degrade a wide variety of organic pollutants into innocuous products (e.g., CO2, H2O) utilizing the inexhaustible and clean solar energy [10,11]. In AOPs, the heterogeneous photocatalysis is an emerging technique valuable for water purification and remediation using semiconductors as environmental photocatalysts. Fundamental and applied research on this subject has been performed extensively during the last 20 years all over the world [12–15]. Illumination of semiconductors such as ZnO and TiO2 with photons of energies greater than the band gap energy promotes electron transition from the valence band to the conduction band, leaving behind positive holes. The valence band potential is positive enough to generate hydroxyl radicals at the semiconductor surface and the conduction band potential is negative enough to reduce molecular O2. The hydroxyl radical and positive hole (h+) are powerful oxidizing agents and attack organic pollutants present at or near the surface of semiconductor photocatalysts, resulting usually in their complete oxidation to CO2 [16–20]. One of the most interesting characteristics of polyoxometalates (POMs) is that they can act as electron relays, i.e. they can undergo stepwise multielectron redox reactions whilst their structure remains intact. Based on this property, POMs have been widely studied as photoxidation catalysts for organic and inorganic pollutants [21–25]. Two catalytic reaction pathways have been proposed: (i) OH attack mechanism [23,26], (ii) precomplexation and subsequently electron or proton transfer between the excited catalysts (POMs*) and substrates [27,28]. The electron transfer between the excited states of POMs* and the ground states of organic compounds can result in the formation of reduced POMs and the radical cations of substrates, and then, the organic substrates are oxidized by oxygen species or hydroxyl radicals. POM anions have also been demonstrated to undergo photochemical reduction with water as an electron donor [29]. On the other hand, a major drawback to the acidic form of POM system is its high water solubility, which impedes recovery and reuse of the catalyst [30]. The acid form has low surface acidity (the number of acidic sites on the surface) because of the low surface area (∼5m2/g) and is highly soluble in water [31]. Various approaches were proposed to solve the problem of low surface areas of POMs. The precipitation of partially saturated Cs+, K+, (NH4)+ or Rb+ salts of POMs results in materials with very high surface areas (more than 100m2/g) where the unreacted acidic clusters are deposited on the surface, and stabilized by interactions with the cations [32,33]. The salts of POMs are considered to be insoluble and they have been studied as photocatalysts for photodegradation of dye pollutants due to their effectiveness and stability [34–36]. We have recently found that cesium phosphomolybate (CsPM) salt is an effective heterogeneous photocatalyst for the photooxidation of BR46 in aqueous condition under simulated sun light irradiation. In this paper, the CsPM photocatalyst with changed surface properties were synthesized by solid-state method. Based on the systematic analysis, a mechanism for the formation of CsPM was proposed. The physicochemical characterizations of the as-prepared CsPM were investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), nitrogen sorption, energy dispersive analysis by X-ray (EDAX) and UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS). The photocatalytic activity of the prepared CsPM photocatalyst was evaluated towards BR46 under simulated solar irradiation. Furthermore, the mechanism of the CsPM photocatalytic activity was investigated by adding the corresponding scavengers of reactive species. To the best of our knowledge, the CsPM nanocluster photocatalyst with excellent photocatalytic activity is reported for the first time, here. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and the synthesis of CsPM There are two methods to synthesize cesium polyoxometalate salts: (i) Solid state method [37] and (ii) Ion exchange method [38]. In our work, the one-step solid-state method was used to synthesize CsPM. The scheme of synthesis of CsPM is shown in Fig. S1 in the Supporting Material. The investigated titanium dioxide, Degussa P25 (having 80% anatase and 20% rutile), was kindly supplied by Degussa Co. (Frankfurt, Germany). The structure and characteristics of BR46 are given in Table S1 in Supporting material [39]. 2.2 Photocatalytic experiments The photocatalytic activity of the prepared CsPM was measured by photodegradation of BR46. Experiments were carried out in a photochemical reactor made of Pyrex glass with the capacity of 50mL equipped with a magnetic stirring bar. Artificial irradiation was provided by a 300W Xenon lamps (HID, the P.R.C) as the simulated solar light. IR radiation and short wavelength UV radiation (λ <380nm) were eliminated by outer jacket of arc tube. Fig. S2 shows the spectra of the xenon lamps (according to the technical report on HID-Xenon 300). The distance between the lamp and the reactor was maintained as 15cm. In a typical experiment, 100mg photocatalyst was added into 50mL of 10mg/L BR46 aqueous solution. Prior to illumination, the suspensions were magnetically stirred for 30min in dark to achieve an adsorption–desorption equilibrium. Then the suspension was exposed to irradiation under magnetic stirring. At certain intervals, aliquots of the suspension (3mL) were sampled and centrifuged. 3mL samples were withdrawn at predetermined time intervals. After measuring the concentration of residual BR46 in the solution by UV–vis spectroscopy (PerkinElmer 550 SE) at λ max equal to 531.0nm, the sample was immediately returned to the reactor. The photocatalytic efficiency was calculated according to the following equation: (1) Degradation Efficiency ( % ) = ( ( C 0 − C ) / C 0 ) × 100 where C 0 is initial concentration of dye (mg/L) in the solution before adding the CsPM. and C is final concentrations of dye (mg/L) in the solution after adding the CsPM at time t. 2.3 Analytical procedures The morphology of the CsPM was observed using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM Model MIRA3/Tescan-Czech Republic) with an accelerating voltage of 3kV after sputter coating with gold under vacuum. The samples were also subjected to energy dispersive analysis by X-ray (EDAX) unit coupled with the above microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis was performed using a Zeiss-EM10C electron microscope operated at 80kV with a point-to-point resolution better than 3.0nm. For TEM observations, the samples were ground in an agate mortar and placed on amorphous carbon-coated copper grids. Textural characteristics of the outgassed samples were obtained from nitrogen physisorption using a Quantachrome instrument, Belsorp mini II (Japan) series to determine the specific surface area, S BET, average cylindrical pore diameters, d p and adsorption pore volume, V pN2. To determine the average crystal size of CsPM, X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out at room temperature by using Siemens X-ray diffraction D5000, with Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.5416Å). The accelerating voltage of 40kV and emission current of 30mA were used. The average crystal size of the CsPM was calculated according to Debye–Scherrer formula [40]. The chemical structures of the CsPM were confirmed using Fourier transform infrared spectrometry (FT-IR, Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer, Germany). The UV–vis diffuse reflection spectra of heteropoly compound samples were measured on a Lambda 950 PerkinElmer spectrometer with integrating sphere. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of CsPM Morphology and structure of the synthesized photocatalyst was investigated by FESEM and TEM images. Fig. S3 shows SEM images of H3PMo12O40 (HPM) and CsPM. As can be seen in Fig. S3(b), HPM clusters are quite irregular in size and shape. This non-uniformity can be attributed to the aggregation of HPM clusters and the growth of irregular crystalline grains during synthesis. A simple comparison between SEM images of HPM (Fig. S3(a) and (b)) and CsPM (Fig. S3(c) and (d)) reveals that the incorporation of cesium into HPM structure restrains the aggregation phenomenon and subsequently decreases the particle size and solubility in water [41] which improves its active surface and photocatalytic activity. Moreover, the presence of cesium ions in the structure increases the shape and size uniformity of synthesized nanoclusters. To clearly see the details of the structure, TEM was employed to further investigate the CsPM, as is shown in Fig. S4. These images show the shapes and particle size of CsPM nanocluster samples. TEM images demonstrate that the particles of CsPM are in nanoscale (40nm) and they are spherical, confirming the results of SEM analysis. The diameter distribution of most of the CsPM particles was found to be in the range of 40–60nm (Fig. S5). Active phase distribution over the surface of CsPM was analyzed by EDAX method (Fig. S3). In order to get representative composition of the photocatalyst, a minimum of four areas of about 500μm×500μm were analyzed on each sample. The analysis was repeated on different particles of the same batch in order to ensure the reproducibility of the obtained results. By this technique the chemical composition of Mo, O, P and Cs elements in CsPM was obtained. EDAX results for CsPM salt shows the presence of molybdenum, phosphorous, oxygen and cesium with no Cl from the Cs salt, suggesting the efficient removal of the excess CsCl. These data are in close agreement with stoichiometric values (Table S2). Sample porosity was elucidated via analysis of their N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms. The cesium salts of POMs had much higher BET surface area (130–200m2/g, measured (than that of the corresponding acids (2–5m2/g) [42,43]. Typically observed N2 adsorption isotherms are presented in Fig. S6, suggesting a typical adsorption curve of type IV according to IUPAC classification. This isotherm exhibit hysteresis loops of H1 type at a relative pressure of p/p°=0.4–0.9. Hysteresis appearing in the multilayer range of physisorption isotherm is usually associated with capillary condensation in mesopore structures. The shape of hysteresis loops are often related to specific pore structures. In our case the hysteresis type H1 is associated with porous materials known to consist of agglomerates of approximately uniform spheres in fairly regular array, and hence to have a narrow distribution of pore size [44]. The results of textural characteristics analysis (BET surface area, BJH pore diameter and average pore volume) for CsPM are given in Table S3. The bulk CsPM salt displayed a surface area of 138m2/g and a pore volume below 0.1cm3/g (Table S3). The pore size distribution curves derived from desorption branch by BJH method [45] are shown in Fig. S6. These curves contain information about the structure of CsPM mesopors. From peak position the diameters of the necks of mesopores of CsPM nanoclusters can be estimated roughly as 165Å. The FT-IR spectra of phosphomolybdic acid and CsPM powders are shown in Fig. S7. In order to confirm the presence of the Keggin anion in CsPM nanocluster, the samples were analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy. The PMo12O40 3− Keggin ion structure consists of a PO4 tetrahedron surrounded by four Mo3O13 units formed by edge-sharing octahedral. These groups are connected to each other by corner sharing oxygen. This structure give rise to four types of oxygen, being responsible for the fingerprint bands of Keggin ion between 1200 and 700cm−1 [37]. FT-IR analyses of acidic POM and POM salt were obtained using KBr wafers in order to detect the vibrational modes of the [PMo12O40]3− anion. Fig. S7 shows an IR spectrum of CsPM containing the main vibrations at 1064–1066cm1, 964–970cm−1, 867–869cm−1, 791–798cm−1 assigned to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of POa, MoOd, MoOb Mo and MoOc Mo corresponding to the Keggin structure [46]. The subscript letters of oxygen atoms in IR spectrum determine the oxygen location in CsPM cluster [47]. The spectra of both forms are almost identical as indicated in Fig. S7, although the spectrum of the water soluble acidic POM showed more intensive water vibrational modes (3450cm−1) than the spectrum of the water-insoluble salt [48]. The lattice structure of the Keggin unit was verified by powder XRD analysis. The wide-angle (2θ =5–60°) patterns for pure CsPM is shown in Fig. 1 . The XRD pattern of the synthesized CsPM salt was well matched with the pattern (Reference code: 046-0481) assigned by the JCPDS (Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards) [49]. 3.2 Optical energy gap In order to explore the Photophysical properties of HPM and CsPM, the measurements of diffuse reflectivity for powder samples were used to achieve their band gaps (E g), which are determined as the intersection point between the energy axis and the line extrapolated from the linear portion of the adsorption edge in a plot of the Kubelka–Munk function [50]. In the diffuse reflectance spectra of pure heteropoly acids the main absorption band in the UV–vis range is due to the ligand-metal charge transfer (LMCT): O2− Mo6+ [51]. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the absorption spectra of HPM one bond centered around 385nm, which is a characteristic bond of heteropolyacids attributed to the O→Mo LMCT. The CsPM present LMCT band with a maximum within 280–550nm and a shoulder with two absorption peaks at 300 and 497nm. The optical properties of samples were studied by the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra were transformed in the Kubelka–Munk function as can be seen in Fig. 2b. It is well known that the optical absorption near the band edge follows the relationship [52]: (2) αhυ = A (hυ − E g) n/2 where α, hυ, A and E g are the absorption coefficient, photon energy (eV), proportionality constant and band gap energy, respectively. The amount of “n” depends on the characteristics of the transition in a semiconductor, i.e., direct transition (n =1) or indirect transition (n =4). Ln (αhυ) is plotted as a function of Ln (hυ − E g) and employ an approximate value of E g to determine the value n with the slope of the straightest line near the band edge [53]. Using this method, the value of n for the CsPM and HPM were approximately 1, meaning that the optical transition is directly allowed. The square of absorption coefficient is linear with energy for direct optical transition in the absorption edge region. The band gap can be estimated by the Kubelka–Munk method. We plot (αhυ)2 dependence on photon energy hυ as shown as in the set (b) in Fig. 2. An extrapolated line of the absorbance is derived from the high slope region of the spectra [54,55]. Then, the band gap is determined by the intercept of the extrapolated line to the hυ axis. As can be seen in Fig. 2b, the calculated band gaps for CsPM nanocluster and HPM were 2.35 and 2.50eV, respectively. According to the results of DRS spectra, the absorbance for CsPM was higher than that of HPM in the range of 380–700nm. This makes it possible to use the CsPM as a photoactive catalyst under sun light irradiation in the photocatalytic process. 3.3 Photodegradation of dyes under simulated sunlight irradiation To exploit the potential application of CsPM, the sunlight-driven photocatalytic degradation was carried out. BR46, existed as a typical organic dye in industrial waste water, was used for catalytic decomposition under the simulated sunlight. Generally, absorption of light by POM at the oxygen to metal charge-transfer (O→MCT) band, enhances their oxidizing ability, and makes them powerful oxidizing reagent able to oxidize a great variety of pollutants in the aquatic environment through a hole–electron mechanism similar to semiconductor photocatalysis [22]. The degradation process was monitored by recording the absorbance spectra of the BR46 aqueous solution. The concentration change of BR46 was estimated based on the characteristic absorption peak of BR46 at 531nm. Fig. 3 shows the UV–vis absorption spectra of the BR46 solution in photocatalytic degradation on the CsPM nanocluster under simulated sunlight at different irradiation times. After 30min from the beginning of the reaction in the dark, because of adsorption of BR46 on the catalyst, the TOC value of the dye solution slightly declined and about 18% of the BR46 was adsorbed on the catalyst. Under irradiation, the TOC decreased slowly. After irradiation for 90min, the dye solution changed to colorless completely, but the surface of CsPM became colorless after irradiation for 240min. 58% of TOC was removed from the dye solution after 240min irradiation. The BR46 is a cationic dye (Table S1) and DLS analysis results showed that the CsPM dispersed in aqueous solution are negatively charged and so, there is a significant adsorption of the dye on the negatively charged catalyst particles. However, most of the degraded intermediates of BR46 are organic acids, which are easily degraded on the surface of the catalyst and released to the solution, which prevents from the poisoning of photocatalyst by the intermediates and makes it reusable [56]. The basic photocatalytic principle of this phenomenon relies on the photogenerated electrons (e−) and holes (h+), produced when the irradiation energy is equal to or higher than the band gap of the photocatalyst. The electrons and holes react with the adsorbed surface substances, like O2 and OH−, to form reactive species O2 −, OH, which is the major oxidative species for the decomposition of organic pollutants [10,11,57]. In most of the proposed mechanisms concerning the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutants, in the presence of POM, the oxidation is supposed to be performed by highly oxidizing OH radicals produced indirectly [58], through the reaction of excited POM with water [59]. Fig. 4 shows the photocatalytic activities of TiO2 and CsPM under the simulated sunlight. The control experiment exhibited negligible activity without CsPM. However, the degradation efficiency of BR46 over CsPM reached 94% after 90min irradiation. The degradation efficiency using pure TiO2 was 28% under the simulated sun light [66]. The results indicated that CsPM had good photo response to simulated sun light irradiation. The experiments confirmed the excellent photocatalytic activity of CsPM under simulated solar light irradiation. Also the photocatalytic activities of CsPM synthesized via solid state and ion exchange methods were compared under simulated sunlight. The results showed that CsPM synthesized via ion-exchange had less photodegradation efficiency in BR46 decolorization (see Fig. 5 ). This is may be due to the agglomeration of catalyst particles under heat treatment [60]. The reduced surface area of the catalyst due to particles aggregation, reduces photodegradation efficiency. 3.4 Detection of active species by scavengers First, the roles of the main active species such as holes, electrons, OH, and O2 − were investigated using different types of active species scavengers. Fig. 5 and Table 1 show the photocatalytic activities of CsPM in the degradation of BR46 under different conditions. Without the addition of scavengers, the photodegradation of BR46 on CsPM was 94% after 90min of irradiation. As we know, the transfer of electrons in the photocatalytic process is very important. The separation of electrons and holes is always recognized to be the initial step in the photodegradation mechanism. Therefore, to investigate the mechanism of the process, scavengers for electrons and holes were first employed to determine the specific reactive species. AgNO3 is an electron scavenger [61]. When the initial BR46 concentration, photocatalyst dosage and scavenger concentration were 10mg/L, 2g/L and 10mg/L, respectively, the photodegradation was reduced to 62% after 90min of irradiation (Fig. 5). The decrease of the amount of electrons reduced the generation of active species such as O2 − and then inhibited the degradation rate. The presence of Ag+ in photocalaytic degradation reaction usually leads to an increase in the rate of organic degradation [62], but in our research is leading to reduced efficiency. The reaction may be initiated by dye sensitization pathway [63], followed by the electron transfer to CsPM. When ammonium oxalate, which was often used as a hole-capturer [64] was added to the reaction system, the photodegradation was reduced to 71% (Fig. 5). The decrease of the amount of holes also influenced the degradation rate. Therefore, it seems that electrons and holes were both important in the process. Photogenerated holes may react with surface hydroxyl groups or adsorbed water to create OH. The OH radicals are very reactive and quickly oxidize organic species at the surface of CsPM. Sulfate, carbonate and chloride ions were used to investigate the effect of the presence of radical scavengers on the photocatalytic degradation of BR46 in aqueous solutions (Table 1). In this set of experiments, the initial BR46 concentration, photocatalyst dosage and radical scavenger concentration were 10mg/L, 2g/L and 5–100mg/L, respectively. It was observed that the decolorization efficiency of BR46 decreased in the presence of all studied radical scavengers, confirming that free radical attack is the dominant controlling mechanism of the photocatalytic degradation of organic dye. As can be seen decreasing effect of carbonate and sulfate anions on decolorization efficiency of BR46 solution was lower than that of chloride ion. Presence of these ions in dye solution inhibited the photocatalytic degradation because of their scavenging effect on reaction of positive holes and reactive radicals [65,66]. With the addition of chloride, carbonate and sulfate, the decolorization efficiency was decreased at the reaction time of 90min (Table 1). The possible reactions that can occur in the presence of different radical scavengers shown as Eqs. (3)–(10), The decrease in degradation efficiency in the presence of chloride ion is due to the hole scavenging properties of chloride ion [67,68]. (3) 2Cl− +2h+ →Cl2 (4) Cl− +OH →HOCl − (5) HOCl − +H+ →Cl +H2O Bhatkhande et al. [69] reported the possibility of generating carbonate radical anion with the help of hydroxyl radicals. Thus the free hydroxyl radical which is a primary source (oxidant) for the photocatalytic degradation decreases with increasing the carbonate ion concentration resulting in the decrease in BR46 degradation efficiency: (6) CO3 2− +OH →CO3 − +OH− (7) 2CO3 − +H2O→2CO2 +HO2 − +OH− (8) HO2 − +OH →HO2 +OH− Table 1 shows the changes in the photocatalytic degradation of BR46 with increasing Na2SO4 concentration. Obviously, with increasing SO4 2− concentration, photocatalytic degradation of BR46 decreased. In the presence of 5mg/L Na2SO4, maximum photocatalytic decolorization was obtained for BR46. When the Na2SO4 concentration was more than 5mg/L, BR46 decolorization decreased. SO4 2− reacts with the positive holes (h+) and hydroxyl radical (OH) and produces SO4 − anion radical, as shown in Eqs. (9) and (10): (9) SO4 2− +h+ →SO4 − (10) SO4 2− +OH →SO4 − +OH− SO4 2− +OH →SO4 − +OH− is less reactive than OH and h+ and therefore, the excess SO4 2− hinders the photocatalytic degradation of [70]. 3.5 Effect of the presence of hydrogen peroxide Addition of powerful oxidizing species, such as hydrogen peroxide to photocatalyst suspensions is a well-known procedure which increases the rate of photooxidation [71,72]. The effect of hydrogen peroxide on the photocatalytic degradation of BR46 was studied and the results are illustrated in Fig. 5. Results show that initial addition of hydrogen peroxide enhances the degradation efficiency of BR46 from 80% to 95% within reaction time of 60min. Hydrogen peroxide is believed to have a dual role during the process of photocatalytic degradation. It accepts an electron from the conduction band, thus, promotes the charge separation and it also forms OH radicals [73]. (11) H2O2 +e− →OH− +OH (12) H2O2 +O2 − →OH− +OH +O2 Thereby, hydrogen peroxide can be considered as a useful chemical for the generation of hydroxyl radicals, which can accelerate the degradation of organic pollutants [74]. The study on the influence of scavenger and enhancer species on dye adsorption was carried out and the results are presented in Fig. 6 . In this study, the initial dye concentration was at 10mg/L and the concentrations of inorganic ions and hydrogen peroxide were adjusted at 10mg/L and 2mM, respectively. Fig. 6 shows that the addition of inorganic ions had a slight effect on the adsorption capacity. These results indicate that the presence of inorganic ions with negative charge have a limited effect on the binding efficiency between CsPM and BR46, because both of the CsPM surface and inorganic molecules are negatively charged that prevents from the adsorption of the anions and their impact on dye adsorption efficiency. Fig. 6 also suggests that the presence of hydrogen peroxide does not play an important role in the adsorption of BR46 from aqueous solution on catalyst surface. But Ag+ ions reduced dye adsorption on the catalyst surface. As mentioned above, the CsPM surface is negatively charged at neutral pH (≈7) and Ag+ was adsorbed on CsPM surface by the electrostatic attraction. Therefore, the CsPM surface charge becomes less negative due to the adsorption of Ag+, leading to the decreased adsorption of BR46 onto catalyst surface. 3.6 Recycle of the catalyst The stability and reusability of catalysts are very important issue for their practical applications. An attractive feature of the POMs is that inherent structure of the catalyst is stable toward oxidative degradation and that the porous solid photocatalyst can be easily separated from the dispersion by simple centrifugation after reaction, which facilitates the reuse of the catalyst. In our study, the stability and reusability of the photocatalyst were investigated by repetitive use of the catalyst. In the first run, 2g/L CsPM was added into 50mL BR46 solution with the concentration of 10mg/L. After 30min in dark, it was exposed to irradiation for 90min and then the remaining dye concentration was measured. CsPM was separated by centrifugation and filtration and dried at 60°C for 2h, then used in the same dye removal experiment. The photodegradation of dye molecule in the second cycle was nearly as fast as in the first run. No significant loss of photoactivity of CsPM was seen in the photocatalytic degradation of BR46 in three consecutive runs, which indicates the considerable stability of the catalyst under the present conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, a water-stable and insoluble photocatalyst was synthesized by solid state method and characterized, then the photocatalytic activity of CsPM in the degradation of Basic Red 46 under simulated sunlight irradiation (λ >380nm) investigated. The CsPM exhibited excellent photocatalytic performance for BR46 degradation. Investigation of the photocatalytic mechanism showed that BR46 photocatalytic degradation using CsPM under simulated sunlight irradiation resulted mainly from direct hole oxidation, and that the concurrent reduction of dissolved oxygen to O2 − occurred. Electron transfer seems to be important in the process, too. CsPM is very stable and easily recovered from the reaction system for reuse. Based on the results of this study, the CsPM photocatalytic system is expected to be effective as a useful sun-light photocatalyst for practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Here the potential use of cesium phosphomolybdate salt as a photocatalyst for the photodegradation of dye pollutants was studied. Polyoxometalates salts, having Keggin structure with large cations like Cs+, are porous materials. Cs3PMo12O40 salt was prepared by solid-state method with a much higher surface area than the original Keggin-type heteropolyacids (H3PMo12O40). The morphological and structural studies of synthesized nanoclusters were carried out using field emission scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, energy dispersive analysis by X-ray and Brunauer–Emmett–Teller. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy determined the absorption edge and band gap energies of the prepared salt as a direct semiconductor. The optical energy gap was calculated equal to 2.35eV. The cesium phosphomolybdate nanocluster exhibited high photodegradation ability for basic red 46 (BR46) under the simulated sunlight. The trapping experiments indicated that the photogenerated hydroxyl radicals and holes were the main responsible for the BR46 photodegradation. The presence of H2O2 significantly improved the photocatalytic activity of cesium phosphomolybdate. The Cs3PMo12O40 catalyst was very stable and easily separated from the reaction media for reuse.
coredata.dc:title: Keggin type of cesium phosphomolybdate synthesized via solid-state reaction as an efficient catalyst for the photodegradation of a dye pollutant in aqueous phase
